De mussen gebruiken de {@creature hawk} stat block maar zijn Constructs die immuun zijn voor gif en psychische schade; de effecten van uitputting; en de {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition petrified}, en {@condition poisoned} condities.

De mussen hebben hun naam in hun borst gegraveerd. (Als een wezen de naam van een mus hardop uitspreekt en hem een opdracht geeft, vliegt hij weg alsof hij door een spreuk {@spell animal messenger} is beïnvloed. Een mechanische mus kan niet alleen gesproken boodschappen overbrengen, maar ook geschreven brieven.

entries.name: Writing Desk
entries: Op de schrijftafel liggen drie brieven, twee van Bavlorna en een van Endelyn:
{@i Sister},

{@i I don't have Elidon's horn. If I did, I would use it to free Bloodybeak and send it after the jabberwock that lairs in the palace and hunts in your forest. No matter what Endelyn says, that burbling beast of a dragon is a threat to our coven and our three realms. How Zybilna managed to befriend it, I'll never know! Maybe we should ask her—ha ha.Much love},
{@i Lorna}
{@i Lovely Skab},

{@i The last time I saw the unicorn horn, it was in your possession. Pity you lost it. But fret not! I have gazed into the Orrery of Tragedies, and it has revealed to me that Elidon's horn will be found}.
{@i If worse comes to worst, recall that Elidon's mate still dwells in your forest. You could kill Lamorna and take her horn—assuming, of course, you're not too busy making toys}.
{@i Your darling sister},
{@i End}
{@i Dear Sister},

{@i There's no use asking Endelyn if she has the horn. She doesn't tell us anything! But if we don't find it soon, I fear what the jabberwock will do after it gets tired of prowling the forest and turns its fiery gaze elsewhere. Gods' bodkins, that thing gives me nightmares}!

{@i Must I remind you that we need a unicorn's horn to free creatures from the cauldron's time-freezing magic? It's not enough to know their true names, you know. Of course, my greater concern is that someone else finds the horn and uses it for exactly that purpose. What do you think Zybilna will do to us, we treacherous three, if she's no longer bound by her cauldron's magic}?
{@i Your beloved sister},
{@i Lorna}

entries.name: From Thither to Yon
entries: Squirt kan de personages op elk moment door de nevelen van Prismeer naar de bergen van Yon leiden. Als de personages Squirt nog niet zijn tegengekomen, stuur hen dan naar Little Oak of laat de boomklever naar hen toekomen. Als Squirt verloren of vernietigd is, kies dan een ander wezen om als gids naar Yon te dienen. Kleine Eik zou een goede keuze zijn.

entries.title: The forest of Thither is home to other strange creatures, including a giant, storytelling spider named {@creature Yarnspinner|DoD}, who is detailed in {@book Domains of Delight|DoD}

data.name: Yon
entries: {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}, de Dame van Ongelukkige Eindes, heerst over dit rijk, en haar voorliefde voor theatraliteit heeft het land om haar heen getransformeerd. Stormwolken wervelen, schaduwen gaan een eigen leven leiden, en de lucht is gevuld met een gevoel van dreigende angst.

Uitgehouwen in de hoogste bergtop van het rijk is Motherhorn, het theater van Endelyn, waar ongelukkige zielen op zoek gaan naar hoop, alleen om te vertrekken na grimmige onthullingen van verval en wanhoop - als ze al vertrekken.

entries.title: Lightning powers the contraptions of Motherhorn, a mountaintop theater where the show must go on

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: In dit hoofdstuk trekken de personages door de gure bergen van Yon, op zoek naar hun verloren voorwerpen of een route naar het Paleis van het Verlangen van het Hart.
Voor uw eerste spelsessie in Yon volgt u deze stappen om de ervaring van de spelers zo onderhoudend mogelijk te maken:

items: Yon wordt geregeerd door {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}, ook bekend als Bitter End, Creeping Lyn, en de Dame of Unhappy Endings. Lees de beschrijving van de heks en blader door haar statistieken in {@area appendix B|459|x}.
Lees dit hoofdstuk in zijn geheel, en maak opnieuw kennis met de "{@area Prismeer Overview|102|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}.
Kijk over de {@adventure map|WBtW|4|Yon} van Yon. Locaties die op de kaart zijn aangegeven, worden later in het hoofdstuk beschreven.

entries: Voordat de personages op Motherhorn aankomen, maak je een kopie van de dialoogregels van Stagefright in {@adventure appendix E|WBtW|10}, knip je ze in reepjes en stop je de reepjes in een ondoorzichtige houder, zoals een papieren zak of een plastic Halloween-ketel. Zie "{@area A Tragedy in the Making|2db|x}" verderop in het hoofdstuk voor hoe de regels van Stagefright in het spel komen.

entries.name: Lost Things in Yon
entries: Als je de "Verloren Dingen" avonturenhaak hebt gebruikt, controleer dan {@adventure Story Tracker|WBtW|11} om te zien of {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} iets of iemand heeft die de personages willen terugwinnen. Als de personages Yon betreden, krijgt iedereen die iets gestolen heeft van de heks, het knagende gevoel dat het ergens in dit rijk is, hoewel het personage niet weet waar. Het gevoel verdwijnt wanneer het personage ofwel terugkrijgt wat verloren was ofwel Yon verlaat zonder het terug te krijgen. Alles wat het personage terug zou willen, wordt bewaard in {@area area M22|34c|x}.

entries.name: Navigating Yon
entries: Beschrijf, met de kaart van Yon als referentie, wat de personages zien als ze hun weg banen door het splintergebied. De talrijke bliksemafleiders van Yon en de andere oriëntatiepunten die in het gedeelte "Ontmoetingen in Yon" worden genoemd, staan op hoge pieken en plateaus en zijn van een afstand gemakkelijk te zien.
Kort na aankomst in Yon ontmoeten de personages een pratende paardenbloem genaamd Amidor, die de weg weet in Yon, waar de personages op een of meer van de volgende locaties kunnen stuiten:

items: Lockbury Henge, een ontmoetingsplaats voor {@creature Korred|VGM|korreds} (zie {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}) die aanwijzingen kan geven over de Brigganock Mijn
Brigganock Mine, waar wensstenen worden opgegraven door kleine wezentjes genaamd {@creature Brigganock|WBtW|brigganocks} (zie {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8})
Rotspilaren, de Fey Beacons, die duidelijk zichtbaar zijn vanaf Lockbury Henge.

entries: Een route naar het Paleis van Hartenwens ligt in de klokkentoren van Motherhorn, waar een zilveren klok hangt die reusachtige kraanvogels oproept als hij wordt geluid. Deze vogels dienen als vliegend rijdier en kunnen de personages naar het paleis brengen. De personages kunnen het paleis ook bereiken via een route over land, maar dan hebben ze een gids nodig die de weg kent. Zonder gids zouden ze hopeloos verdwalen in de bergen van Yon.

entries.name: Guide from Yon to Hither or the Palace of Heart's Desire
entries: {@creature Amidor the Dandelion|WBtW|Amidor}, een stoere paardenbloem, kan de personages van Yon naar Hither en terug naar Yon leiden. Hij weet ook een veilige route over land naar de {@adventure Palace of Heart's Desire|WBtW|5}. De personages ontmoeten Amidor kort na hun aankomst in Yon (zie "{@area Arrival in Yon|299|x}" hieronder).

entries.name: Features of Yon
entries: Yon is een rijk van rotsachtige pieken, onweerswolken en gierende winden. De smalle richels en voetpaden die zich rond de bergen kronkelen maken het mogelijk te voet te reizen, maar deze routes zijn moeilijk en doodlopende wegen zijn gebruikelijk. De schichtige geiten springen en lopen met gemak over de berghellingen, maar ze mijden vreemden. Om verder dan een kilometer of twee te kunnen kijken, moet men naar hooggelegen gebieden klimmen, waar de regen en de wind bijzonder hevig zijn.

entries.name: Lightning Rods
entries: {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} heeft koperen bliksemafleiders op bergtoppen in heel Yon geplaatst en gebruikt ze om de elektriciteit van de stormen op te vangen, die op hun beurt de toestellen in haar theater van stroom voorzien. Elke bliksemafleider is 30 voet hoog en bekroond met een 10 voet groot symbool van een zon of maan, gemaakt van koper. Elk uur ontladen de bliksemafleiders de opgehoopte elektriciteit en sturen bliksemschichten door de lucht naar de bliksemafleiders boven op Motherhorn.

Elke bliksemafleider is een enorm voorwerp met AC 17, 75 hit points en immuniteit tegen bliksem-, gif- en psychische schade. Een bliksemafleider heeft veel hand- en voetensteunen, zodat hij zonder check kan worden beklommen. Hij kan worden omgegooid door er touwen aan vast te maken en hem dan omver te trekken, wat ofwel een succesvolle DC 30 Kracht ({@skill Athletics}) check vereist, ofwel de inspanning van meerdere wezens met een gecombineerde Kracht van 60 of hoger. Een roede kan niet worden omgegooid door aan de basis te trekken of te duwen.

entries.name: Arrival in Yon
entries: Als de personages voor het eerst in Yon aankomen, lees dan:

Je staat op een pad dat tussen rotsachtige rotsen op een berghelling kronkelt. De lucht is donker en zit vol met kolkende donderwolken. Je wordt begroet door een gierende wind. Even splijt de bliksem de hemel, slaat in op nabije bergtoppen en verlicht een verre rotspunt waar een dreigend kasteel in is uitgehouwen.
Het kasteel in de verte is Motherhorn. Welke kant de personages opgaan, is aan hen. Welke weg ze ook kiezen, ze komen niet ver voordat ze een andere vriendelijke gids tegenkomen.

entries.name: Amidor and Gleam
entries: Deze ontmoeting moet plaatsvinden voordat de personages hun eerste willekeurige ontmoeting in Yon hebben of een van de gemarkeerde locaties op de kaart van Yon bereiken.

Je ziet twee figuren op een rotspunt staan, afgetekend tegen de stormachtige lucht. De ene is een slanke vrouwelijke elf met een maansikkelmasker, en de andere is een drie meter hoge paardenbloem met een klein rapier aan zijn steel. Een honingbij zo groot als een sinaasappel zoemt rond het felgele hoofd van de paardenbloem.
De elf is de eerste die je opmerkt. Als ze in jouw richting wijst, trekt de paardenbloem zijn rapier en neemt een defensieve houding aan. De honingbij zoemt luider en vliegt rondjes om de twee.

Het wezen dat het rapier hanteert is {@creature Amidor the Dandelion|WBtW|Amidor}, en zijn geliefde metgezel is {@creature Pollenella the Honeybee|WBtW|Pollenella} (zie de bijbehorende stat blocks). De gemaskerde figuur is Gleam, een hoge elf acrobaat (gebruik het {@creature Selenelion twin|WBtW} stat blok in {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}) van het Heksenlicht Carnaval. Wanneer de bliksem flitst in de donkere lucht, is het gemakkelijk te zien dat Gleam geen schaduw werpt. Terwijl ze geen schaduw heeft, is Gleam vervloekt (zie de "Schaduwloze" zijbalk).

entries.name: Shadowless
entries: Een schaduwloos wezen is een wezen dat de vloek draagt geen schaduw te hebben - een feit dat alleen duidelijk wordt als het wezen in fel of zwak licht staat. Een {@spell remove curse} spreuk of soortgelijke magie beëindigt de vloek op een schaduwloos wezen en herenigt het onmiddellijk met zijn schaduw.
Inheemse wezens in Prismeer zullen een bekend schaduwloos wezen of iemand die zich met een schaduwloos wezen verbindt, niet vertrouwen of er zaken mee doen.

Personages die Gleam's {@creature detached shadow|WBtW} hebben ontmoet in het Heksenlicht Carnaval merken op dat Gleam's halve maan masker dezelfde vorm heeft als het masker dat door haar schaduw wordt gedragen.

Als de personages vriendelijk lijken, smeken Amidor en Gleam hen om hulp. Als tegenprestatie biedt Amidor zijn diensten als gids aan. Tijdens het gesprek dat volgt, delen Amidor en Gleam vrijelijk de volgende informatie:

items: Amidor is op de vlucht nadat hij Pollenella, een bijenkoningin, heeft bevrijd van een cyclops imker. De twee kruisen hun pad met Gleam, en na het horen van het zielige verhaal van de elf, besluit Amidor haar te helpen.

{@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} heeft met een magische schaar de schaduw van Gleam afgeknipt en heeft haar tweelingzus Glister gevangen gezet. De regel van gastvrijheid (zie "{@area Rules of Conduct|105|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}) voorkomt dat de heks Glister iets aan kan doen, maar Gleam kan het verdriet van haar zus voelen. De tweeling werkt als een acrobatisch duo, en ze waren vroeger sterspelers in het Heksen Carnaval. Gleam wil haar zus bevrijden en een weg terug vinden naar het carnaval - misschien met de hulp van de Fey Beacons (zie "{@area Fey Beacons|2ba|x}" verderop in het hoofdstuk).

Endelyn gelooft dat haar eigen ondergang zal plaatsvinden tijdens een eclips. Omdat er geen maan aan de hemel boven Yon staat, gaat de heks ervan uit dat de eclips een symbolische vertoning zal zijn, in plaats van een letterlijke. Omdat de Selenelion tweeling de levende belichaming is van de maan en de zon, besloot de heks de elfenzusjes te scheiden, de ene vrij te laten en de andere als haar "gast" te houden. Door de tweeling apart te houden, hoopt de heks haar ondergang te voorkomen.

entries: Toen zij te gast was in Motherhorn, kwam Gleam de volgende informatie te weten, die zij deelt met personages die beloven haar te helpen:

entries.title: {@creature Amidor the Dandelion|WBtW|Amidor} and {@creature Pollenella the Honeybee|WBtW|Pollenella}

items: De bergen zijn het thuis van korreds - stevige Fey wezens wiens haar de kracht van ijzer heeft. De korreds komen samen en dansen bij Lockbury Henge. (Als de personages er zelf niet opkomen, stelt Gleam voor dat ze een verbond sluiten met de korreds. Zie "{@area Lockbury Henge|2b0|x}" verderop in het hoofdstuk voor hoe ze dat zouden kunnen doen).

Een elfenprins genaamd {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} heeft een afspraak gemaakt met Endelyn en zit nu vast in Yon. Hij is bij de Fey Beacons, op zoek naar een weg naar huis (zie "{@area Fey Beacons|2ba|x}" verderop in het hoofdstuk voor meer informatie).

Hurly, een insectenbeer, heeft een afspraak gemaakt met Endelyn en is niet blij met hoe de dingen gelopen zijn. Nu is hij gedwongen op te treden in haar morbide theater. Net als Gleam werkte Hurly vroeger voor {@creature Mister Witch|WBtW} en {@creature Mister Light|WBtW}, maar Gleam en haar broer hadden de kermis al verlaten toen Hurly en zijn broer Burly arriveerden. (Gleam weet dat Hurly graag zijn broer weer wil zien, en ze wil hem graag helpen als ze kan).

entries: {@adventure Appendix D|WBtW|9} heeft extra rollenspel aantekeningen voor Amidor en Gleam.

entries.name: Development
entries: Amidors eerste zorg is de veiligheid van Pollenella, maar de paardenbloem probeert ook zijn beloften na te komen om Gleam en de personages te helpen. Eer dicteert dat Amidor Gleam herenigt met haar tweelingzus voordat hij de personages naar Hither of het Paleis van Hartenwens leidt.

Amidor is niet alleen de gids van de personages in Yon, hij is ook de feitelijke leider van hun gezelschap van gidsen, waartoe op dit moment ook {@creature Clapperclaw the scarecrow|WBtW} en {@creature Squirt the oilcan|WBtW} kunnen behoren.

Als je je bezwaard voelt door al deze niet-speelfiguren, geef ze dan verantwoordelijkheden die niet veel van je aandacht vragen. Clapperclaw's belangrijkste taak kan bijvoorbeeld zijn om Squirt te dragen, terwijl Amidor bijna al zijn tijd kan besteden aan het waken over de andere gidsen en het fluisteren van lieve woordjes tegen Pollenella. In gevechten kun je deze ondersteunende personages de {@action Dodge} actie laten uitvoeren of, als de omstandigheden dat vereisen, de {@action Help} actie. Dit heeft als bijkomend voordeel dat de spelerspersonages het middelpunt van het avontuur worden.

entries.name: Random Encounters in Yon
entries: Een willekeurige ontmoeting in Yon vindt plaats wanneer jij dat wilt. Om te bepalen wat de personages tegenkomen, rol je een {@dice d8} en raadpleeg je de Random Encounters in Yon tabel. Als je hetzelfde resultaat krijgt als een vorige worp, kies dan een andere ontmoeting waarvan je denkt dat die leuk zou zijn.

entries.name: Astronomer's Throne
entries: De personages komen een troon tegen, gehouwen uit een rotsblok en geëtst met astronomische symbolen. Een spreuk {@spell detect magic} onthult een aura van waarzeggerij rond de troon. Een inscriptie in het Elfs, gegraveerd rond de troonzitting, luidt:
{@i I am a traveler from a distant land.}
{@i My name is Mazikoth, Keeper of Stars}.
{@i Sit on my throne, disciple, and unravel.}

Elk personage dat slaagt voor een DC 20 Intelligentie ({@skill Arcana} of {@skill History}) check herinnert zich dat Mazikoth een elf was en een gevierd astronoom die beweerde afkomstig te zijn van een zwarte ster aan de rand van de nacht.

Een wezen dat op de troon zit, begint het koud en slaperig te krijgen. Het eerste wezen dat ten minste 1 minuut op de troon blijft zitten, raakt in een magische trance die 1 uur duurt. In deze trance is het wezen zich niet bewust van zijn omgeving, terwijl het droomt dat het door de ruimte raast in de richting van een verre, dode ster. Aan het einde van de droom komt het wezen aan op het koude oppervlak van de ster en schrikt wakker, omdat hij een fragment van de psyche van Mazikoth heeft geërfd. Het wezen wordt vaardig in één van de volgende vaardigheden (zijn keuze): {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Deception}, {@skill History}, {@skill Insight}, {@skill Intimidation}, of {@skill Survival}.
Zodra de troon zijn gave aan een schepsel heeft geschonken, is de troon een jaar lang niet meer magisch en gebeurt er niets als een schepsel erop gaat zitten.

entries.name: Awakened Giant Goats
entries: De personages komen drie {@creature Giant Goat||giant goats} geiten tegen, die elk het voordeel van een {@spell awaken} spreuk hebben gekregen, waardoor hun intelligentiescore tot 10 is gestegen en ze Elfish kunnen spreken. Deze geiten hebben een zilvergrijze vacht, een verweerd gezicht en goudkleurige zandlopervormige pupillen die de personages nauwlettend in de gaten houden.
De geiten kunnen profetieën en geheimen horen die door de wind worden gefluisterd. Bij het zien van de personages, blaten de geiten het volgende:

items: De eerste geit zegt: "Als de maan de zon belemmert, zal Creeping Lyn ongedaan worden gemaakt." (Deze profetie verwijst naar de zwakte van Endelyn, zoals beschreven in {@area appendix B|461|x}.)

De tweede geit zegt, "Speel op haar passies. Blijf bij het script. Een kat, een hoorn, of een geripte schaduw." (Deze voorspelling verwijst naar Endelyns verlangen om toneelstukken voor haar te laten opvoeren en naar de drie dingen die zij bereid is te accepteren als resultaat van een overeenkomst met de personages, zoals besproken in "{@area Bargaining with Endelyn|2d8|x}" sectie verderop in het hoofdstuk).

De derde geit zegt: "De scepter van de dwaas is de sleutel." (Deze uitspraak verwijst naar de scepter die toebehoort aan Stagefright de kobold, die gebruikt kan worden om de stenen deur naar {@area area M17|32f|x} te openen).

entries: Na het uitspreken van deze woorden wachten de geiten om te zien of de personages hen iets in ruil aanbieden, waarmee ze de regel van wederkerigheid in acht nemen (zie "{@area Rules of Conduct|105|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}). De geiten hebben honger, maar zijn geen kieskeurige eters, hoewel ze toegeven dat ze dol zijn op knolgewassen. Als er geen tegenprestatie komt, in de vorm van voedsel of andere geschenken, rennen alle drie de geiten weg terwijl een {@creature galeb duhr} uit de grond onder hen barst. Dit Elementaal kan niet spreken en is een manifestatie van de woede van de Feywild jegens de personages. Hij valt de groep aan en vecht tot hij vernietigd is. Er zijn veel rotsblokken in het gebied die de Galeb duhr kan animeren met zijn actie Animeer rotsblokken.

entries.title: Mudlump the cyclops searches for his missing queen bee

entries.name: Cyclops Beekeeper
entries: Een {@creature cyclops} imker genaamd Mudlump stuit op de personages terwijl hij op zoek is naar Pollenella, zijn verloren bijenkoningin. Mudlump draagt een sluier met capuchon om zijn ogen te beschermen tegen bijensteken en draagt een grote bijenkorf op een stok, die ook dienst doet als knots. Drie maal per dag kan Mudlump, als actie, met zijn bijenkorf schudden om een zwerm bijen tevoorschijn te brengen; behandel elke zwerm als een {@creature Swarm of Wasps||swarm of insects (wasps)}. De zwerm valt de vijanden van Mudlump aan.

Als Amidor bij het gezelschap is, zwaait de paardenbloem zijn rapier om zijn geliefde honingbij te verdedigen. Bij het zien van Amidor, brult de cyclops in reus, "Jij hebt de bijenkoningin gestolen! Mudlump heeft koningin nodig om honing mede te maken! Beste honingwijn in Yon!" Amidor spreekt geen Reus en heeft geen idee wat de cyclops zegt, maar Mudlump's verontwaardiging komt luid en duidelijk door.

Mudlump spreekt geen andere taal dan reusachtig. Elk karakter dat met Mudlump kan communiceren kan, met een succesvolle DC 13 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, hem overtuigen om Amidor of het gezelschap niet aan te vallen. Hier zijn drie mogelijkheden om het geschil op te lossen, maar slimme spelers kunnen ook andere bedenken:

items.name: Honorable Duel
items.entry: De personages overtuigen Mudlump om deel te nemen aan een eervol duel tegen een van hen. Als Mudlump wint, krijgt hij Pollenella; als hij verliest, laat hij Amidor Pollenella houden en valt hij het gezelschap niet meer lastig.

items.name: Magical Deception
items.entry: De personages gebruiken magie om Mudlump voor de gek te houden of te sussen. Een personage kan bijvoorbeeld een illusie van Pollenella creëren die de cycloop lang genoeg voor de gek houdt zodat het gezelschap kan ontsnappen. Of een personage kan een {@spell speak with animals} spreuk gebruiken om uit te vinden wat Pollenella wil. De bij blijft liever bij Amidor dan dat hij terugkeert naar de cycloop; als Mudlump de spreuk ziet en te weten komt wat Pollenella's voorkeur heeft, laat hij Amidor de bij houden.

items.name: Explain Love to Mudlump
items.entry: De personages vertellen Mudlump dat Amidor en Pollenella verliefd zijn. Deze verklaring zorgt ervoor dat de cycloop verward met zijn ogen knippert en vraagt: "Wat is liefde?" Als het concept aan hem wordt uitgelegd, verklaart Mudlump dat hij ook wel verliefd zou willen zijn en geeft hij de personages een zoektocht om zijn ware liefde te vinden. Hoewel de personages kunnen proberen Mudlump te koppelen aan elk wezen dat zij geschikt achten, is zijn ideale match te vinden in het Paleis van Hartenlust: de fomoriaan Dubhforgail (zie {@area area P18|3a2|x} in {@adventure chapter 5|WBtW|5}).

entries.name: Mudlump's Home
entries: If Mudlump survives this encounter, he returns to his home in the tumbledown, moss-covered ruins of a 30-foot-diameter stone tower that once protruded from a mountainside. There, in a small garden, the cyclops has cultivated three fat, 6-foot-tall mushrooms. These fungi have been hollowed out and turned into casks, their caps serving as lids. These casks are used to ferment a mixture of water and honey, which Mudlump combines with other ingredients to make honey mead. A great beehive—considerably larger than the one Mudlump carries around—fills an ancient, rotted-out tree stump on one side of the tower. The stump is 10 feet tall, twice as wide, and has openings at the top through which Mudlump can reach into the hive. A 6-foot-high, 3-foot-wide, naturally formed opening on one side of the stump leads to a cavity filled with honeycombs and swarming with bees. (Amidor used this opening to enter the hive and rescue Pollenella.)

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Mudlump has hidden the following treasures under loose stones throughout his home. Any character can find these items with a thorough search of the ruins:

items: An empty crystal vial shaped like a pixie, dangling on the end of a delicate silver chain (75 gp)
An untuned lyre of exquisite quality (250 gp)
A {@item quiver of Ehlonna}

entries.name: Evil Kite
entries: Feenia, an unhappy goblin child (neutral) in overalls, flies a kite on a blustery plateau. The kite is alive, has a hideous face stretched over its diamond-shaped frame, and cackles in the wind. The kite's 40-foot-long string has five blue bows tied along its length at 8-foot intervals, starting about 5 feet from Feenia's end of the string and ending 5 feet away from the kite.

Feenia's goblin parents, Specklenose and Zolt, live and work in Motherhorn. Three days ago, Feenia was caught stealing theater props, but {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} promised not to punish her as long as Feenia agreed to fly the hag's kite. Feenia did so and is now unable to let go of the cursed thing. Yanking the string from Feenia's grasp releases the goblin child from the pact but also ages her 10 years for every bow that is attached to the kite. The most she can age is 50 years—enough to transform her into a crone with skin like a shriveled apple.
Feenia speaks Common and Goblin. If the characters approach her, she shares the following information while the kite taunts her from above:

"My arms are so very sore, I don't want to fly this kite anymore! But if I let go of this string, Creeping Lyn says I'll become an old thing! The curse comes from those five blue bows, but they won't come off while the wind blows."

The kite, which was created and brought to life by Endelyn, is a Small animated object (see the {@spell animate objects} spell for its statistics). The bows can't be removed from the string while the kite is in the air, and the string can't be cut. The kite, its string, and the bows turn to ashes if the kite is reduced to 0 hit points.

The safest way to free Feenia from the kite without aging her is to untie the bows, which can be accomplished only while the kite is on the ground (see "The Kite Falls" below). Once the kite falls to the ground, it takes an action to untie each bow. Another way to free Feenia is to reduce the kite to 0 hit points with a single attack or effect before it can react (see "The Kite Reacts" below).

entries.name: The Kite Falls
entries: A character who doesn't know what else to do can use an action to make a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. On a successful check, the character senses a correlation between Feenia's foul mood and the strength of the wind around her. If the kite's taunts are muted for at least 1 minute using a {@spell silence} spell or similar magic, Feenia's mood improves, causing the wind to abate and the kite to fall. The same thing happens if a character uses an action to try to calm Feenia, doing so with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, or if the goblin receives the benefit of a {@spell calm emotions} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: The Kite Reacts
entries: If the kite takes damage, but not enough to reduce it to 0 hit points, it uses its reaction to yank the string from Feenia's grasp (causing Feenia to age as described above). On subsequent turns, the untethered kite flies away.

entries.name: Development
entries: Regardless of how this encounter plays out, Feenia is not happy about returning to Motherhorn as long as Creeping Lyn is there. She is aware of a small cave nearby where she can hide, and she can survive there indefinitely by eating moss and lizards.

Feenia has a trinket hidden in the pocket of her overalls. She gives this trinket to the characters if they rid her of the kite without causing her to age. Roll on the Feywild Trinkets table in the introduction to determine the trinket.

entries.name: Goblin Procession
entries: Eight {@creature Goblin||goblins} (neutral) shuffle into view, solemnly ringing handbells. They wear headdresses made from animal skulls (badgers, wolves, and rams) and are further adorned with necklaces of dangling bones. Known as the Dead Ringers, they sound their bells to comfort the dead, whom they believe lie in the rock beneath their feet.

The goblins are interested in talking to strangers and are willing to trade their services for a trinket. They have the power to commune with the dead by forming a circle and ringing their bells. (A minimum of three goblins are needed to perform the ritual.) After 1 minute of this clamor, the ephemeral spirit of a {@creature korred|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}) or some other departed Fey creature rises from the ground between the goblins. The spirit answers three questions put to it, as though it was targeted by a {@spell speak with dead} spell. Use the spirit to communicate as much useful information as you want; ideally, the characters should learn at least one fact that might help them in a future encounter.
The goblins require one trinket as payment each time they commune with a spirit. After performing this ritual three times, the goblins must finish a long rest to regain their spirit-summoning power.

entries.name: Goblin Shadows
entries: {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} separates Humanoids from their shadows using a pair of magic scissors. These severed shadows, indebted to the hag for granting them their freedom, have become a minor menace to travelers.

Characters who have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher observe two silent shadows creeping up behind them. Each one looks like the slightly {@creature Detached Shadow|WBtW|elongated shadow} of a goblin; both use the {@creature shadow} stat block, except they are Fey rather than Undead. The shadows can't leave Yon but otherwise try to follow the characters wherever they go, making spooky and threatening gestures but without causing any harm. If they are attacked, the shadows attack in turn. If one shadow is destroyed, the other tries to flee.

A creature whose Strength is reduced to 0 by a shadow's Strength Drain attack does not die but falls {@condition unconscious} instead. The creature regains consciousness and the reduction to its Strength score disappears after it finishes a short or long rest.

entries.name: Pageant Wagon
entries: A wooden pageant wagon trundles toward the party on squeaky wheels. It moves by itself at a speed of 20 feet and is accompanied by a tall figure swathed in long robes and a cowl. The wagon is painted with stormy, windswept landscapes and carries a puppet theater with black velvet curtains drawn across it.

The wagon stops near the characters, and the curtains pull back to reveal a painted backdrop that matches the environment in which the characters stand. Marionettes representing each of the characters dance on the stage and begin to reenact a recent scene from the party's time in Yon.

The marionettes, the wagon, and its attendant are magically animated. If the characters touch the hooded figure, it collapses into a pile of robes. If they try to board the wagon, it falls apart into a heap of wood scraps as thunder booms and lightning flashes overhead.

The play is 3 minutes long and ends with a scene that shows the characters standing around a tiny replica of the pageant wagon. A banner emblazoned with the words "To be continued!" unfurls in front of the scene, and then the curtains close. From the folds of its robes, the hooded figure presents a document to each character. Each one looks like a ticket with a tiny puppet resembling the character painted on it. Written under this effigy in script that the recipient understands (regardless of what languages it knows) are these words: "Good for one private audience with {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}—no strings attached!" After the invitations are handed out, the wagon and its attendant disappear abruptly.

entries.name: Tornado
entries: The sky darkens as a huge tornado forms and careens toward the characters. Everyone in the party (characters and nonplayer characters) must make a DC 17 Strength saving throw. If at least half of the party members succeed on the saving throw, none of them are swept away by the tornado.

If less than half of them succeed on the saving throw, the tornado whisks the group to a location determined by rolling on the Tornado Destinations table. Each party member takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) force damage and falls {@condition prone} upon landing. In addition, any character whose saving throw failed by 5 or more loses one nonmagical item in transit (determined by you). The item should be something that could reasonably be snatched away by the wind, such as a belt pouch or a helmet. This item is not recoverable.

entries.caption: Tornado Destinations
rows: Outside Brigganock Mine (see "{@area Brigganock Mine|2c1|x}" later in the chapter)
Inside Lockbury Henge (see "{@area Lockbury Henge|2b0|x}" later in the chapter)
Atop one of the Fey Beacons (see "{@area Fey Beacons|2ba|x}" later in the chapter)
Outside Motherhorn's main entrance ({@area area M1|2e4|x})
On the stage in Motherhorn's amphitheater ({@area area M2|2e8|x})
In the garden of the Palace of Heart's Desire (see {@area area P2|36d|x} in {@adventure chapter 5|WBtW|5})

entries.name: Locations in Yon
entries: The following encounters take place at locations marked on the map of Yon. As the characters explore Yon, you can move these locations as needed, putting them in the characters' path. These locations can be explored in any order, or not at all:
{@area Lockbury Henge.|2b0|x} This henge sits atop a rocky plateau. The characters might come here hoping to forge an alliance with the korreds of Yon.
{@area Fey Beacons.|2ba|x} An elf prince named {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} is doomed to light fires atop these pinnacles of rock until he finds a way back home. The characters can help him or not.

{@area Brigganock Mine.|2c1|x} The korreds of Yon are at loggerheads with the brigganocks who inhabit this mine. The characters might visit the mine in the hope of uniting the brigganocks and the korreds, or in search of a hero willing to help them. Inside the mine, they encounter a member of Valor's Call (see {@area appendix B|494|x}) and discover a secret way into {@adventure Motherhorn|WBtW|4}.

entries.name: Lockbury Henge
entries: Yon is home to eight clans of {@creature Korred|VGM|korreds}. Queen Argantle, elected to rule over all eight clans, protects this sacred site. Lockbury Henge is meant to be a place where korreds can enjoy each other's company while singing, dancing, and playing games.

Argantle is playing a chess-like game called Crowns with her cousin, Jagu, when a howling wind warns her of the party's approach, giving her and Jagu enough time to stamp out the flame of their campfire and make themselves scarce before the characters arrive.

Atop a boulder-strewn plateau stands a circle of eight megaliths. In the center of this henge, a small, checkered game board with stone playing pieces rests on the ground near the dying embers of a campfire.

Each of the eight standing stones is about 20 feet tall and hewn from a different kind of rock: shale, chalk, flint, granite, slate, basalt, obsidian, and marble. Two {@creature Korred|VGM|korreds} (see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}) are using {@spell meld into stone} spells to hide in two of the megaliths: Argantle of Shale in the one made of shale, and Jagu of Chalk (leader of the Chalk Clan korreds) in the one made of chalk. While hidden in this way, the korreds can see their surroundings as though the standing stones were transparent instead of opaque. Characters who examine the campfire and succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check notice two sets of small, sooty hoofprints leading up to the stones where the korreds are hiding.

entries.name: Brigganocks and Korreds
entries: The {@creature Brigganock|WBtW|brigganocks} who live under the mountains of Yon are at odds with the {@creature Korred|VGM|korreds} who live on the slopes and peaks. Each group believes that the other is in league with {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}, not realizing that the hag is a menace to both. The characters encounter the korreds at Lockbury Henge and the brigganocks at Brigganock Mine. For more information about these Fey creatures, see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}.

If the characters discover that the brigganocks are not allied with Endelyn and convey this information to the korreds, Queen Argantle of the korreds promptly arranges a meeting with the brigganocks to sort out their differences. Similarly, if the characters convince the brigganocks that the korreds don't work for Endelyn, the brigganocks agree to meet the korreds outside the mine. After this meeting, the korreds and the brigganocks unite to aid the characters in Motherhorn (as described in the "{@area Fey to the Rescue!|2d9|x}" sidebar later in the chapter).

Argantle and Jagu emerge from their megaliths if the characters properly finish the korreds' game of Crowns (see "Game Board" below). If the characters ruin the game, deface the standing stones, or otherwise irritate the korreds, Argantle and Jagu emerge from their megaliths and attack the characters for their insolence. Otherwise, the rule of hospitality (see "{@area Rules of Conduct|105|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}) prevents the korreds from harming the characters. {@adventure Appendix D|WBtW|9} has additional roleplaying notes for Argantle.

As an action, Argantle can call forth the remaining six leaders of the korred clans of Yon, each one emerging from its corresponding megalith. If combat breaks out, these six {@creature Korred|VGM|korreds} help Argantle capture the characters for questioning. The other korred clan leaders are Budoc of Flint, Azil of Granite, Myzelda of Slate, Yanna of Basalt, Noll of Obsidian, and Malo of Marble.

The korreds of Yon despise {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}, whom they commonly refer to as Bitter End. If the characters convince Argantle that they also consider the hag an enemy, she reveals the following:

items: The korreds no longer hold large gatherings at Lockbury Henge. Argantle fears the consequences of Bitter End's meddling and has instructed her fellow korreds to ensconce themselves in stone, thus remaining in relative safety for the foreseeable future.
Bitter End used iron shears to cut off locks of Argantle's hair. The hag fashions korred hair into iron ropes and uses them to manipulate her theater's infernal contraptions.
Bitter End uses a contraption called the Orrery of Tragedies to glimpse all possible futures. Copper rods on the mountaintops of Yon capture lightning and channel it into this device.

entries.name: Game Board
entries: An examination of the checkered board reveals that the pieces depict a game in progress. Two sets of playing pieces, one made of shale and the other of chalk, are sculpted in the form of tiny korreds (cloven-hoofed creatures with wild beards and hair). If the characters have already visited Brigganock Mine, they see that the game pieces resemble the leering statues outside the mine's entrance.

Characters who study the arrangement of the pieces on the board and succeed on a DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Insight}) check determine that Slate can beat Chalk in a single move. Making this move causes the victorious Queen Argantle to emerge from her stone, laughing and cheering. Jagu emerges grumpily to join her, chewing on pebbles and glaring at the characters.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The character who helped Argantle win the game receives a gift, in accordance with the rule of reciprocity (see "{@area Rules of Conduct|105|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}). Argantle picks up a lump of rock, squeezes it tightly between her hands to transform it into a {@item star sapphire} (1,000 gp), and gives it to the character. If the gift is accepted, the gemstone begins to glow faintly. Until it stops glowing 24 hours later, the star sapphire has the properties of a {@item stone of good luck} that doesn't require attunement.

entries.name: Distant Racket
entries: Any conversation between the characters and the korreds is interrupted by a commotion:

The korreds grind their teeth and stamp their hooves as the faint sound of pickaxes tapping on stone is carried to them on the wind. Queen Argantle runs to a boulder, picks it up, and hurls it a hundred feet in the direction of the noise while she screams, "Death to the brigganocks!" A peal of thunder accompanies this display of anger.
The korreds, who are feuding with the brigganocks of Yon, share the following information with characters who look like they might be capable of assisting:

items: The brigganocks are helping Bitter End build wicked contraptions. They also hide and guard schematic diagrams for new contraptions in their mine. (The korreds are mistaken. The hag terrorizes the brigganocks and has kidnapped their chief architect, forcing him to work under duress in {@adventure Motherhorn|WBtW|4}.)
The korreds can't stand the noise of the brigganocks' mining, so they craft statues and leave them outside the mine's entrance, hoping to frighten the brigganocks into leaving.

A galeb duhr working for the korreds infiltrated the mine and overheard several brigganocks talking about a secret tunnel that connects the mine to Motherhorn. The tunnel is hidden by brigganock magic.

entries.name: Korred Dance
entries: The noise of the mining soon passes. If the korreds are well disposed toward the characters, Queen Argantle becomes elated at the prospect of their assistance, drums her hooves on the ground, and begins the first korred ceremonial dance since the rise of the Hourglass Coven. If she hasn't done so already, Argantle summons the other korred leaders so they can join in:
Two korreds drum on boulders as the others stomp their feet and jump around. The rain abates, and the sky lightens. With wild grins and wilder hair, the dancing korreds beckon you to join them.

Any character who joins the boisterous dance can impress the korreds with a successful DC 14 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check. Characters who get a success on either check are taught a special jig which, when performed as an action, allows them to manipulate any korred hair they find in Motherhorn as if using the korreds' Command Hair trait.

entries.name: Development
entries: The accompanying "{@area Brigganocks and Korreds|2b2|x}" sidebar describes how the characters can facilitate a truce between the two groups of Fey and unite them against {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}.

entries.name: Fey Beacons
entries: In this encounter, a cursed prince trying to find his way home is thwarted by a troupe of perytons. If they want, the characters can intervene on the prince's behalf, or they can simply take in the sights and move on:

Eight columns of rock reach skyward, forming a ring around a deep crater lake. Rough-hewn steps spiral up each of the columns, and a rowboat is moored on the lakeshore next to one of them. A torch-bearing figure trudges up the stairs on the column nearest to the rowboat. Eight winged beasts with antlers shout and howl with laughter as they circle and wheel around it.

The columns of rock are 200 feet tall and 150 feet apart. Each one has a large copper brazier at its summit. These braziers aren't visible from below the columns' summits, but all eight can be seen from the top of any column or by a creature flying at that elevation or higher. The lake is 400 feet in diameter and 100 feet deep at its center.

The figure is {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW}, a wood elf prince from the Material Plane. As the characters watch from afar, he reaches the top of the column he is ascending and uses his torch to light the beacon there. The beacon burns bright as he descends the stairs and boards the rowboat. As the elf rows toward the next beacon, the eight {@creature Peryton||perytons} that had been harassing him extinguish the flame in the brazier with powerful beats of their wings. {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} believes the fiery beacons can show him the way home, but only while all of them are lit.

entries.title: The Greyhawk Mummers are actors who were transformed into perytons by fey magic

entries.name: Prince Alagarthas
entries: After several failed attempts to fend off a green dragon threatening the prosperity of his kingdom, {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} caught the eye of {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}, who visited him on his home world of Toril. The hag showed the prince a future in which he defeated the dragon but lost his life in the process. Endelyn also claimed to see an alternate future in which the dragon was defeated and {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} survived; she would share the details of her vision with {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW}, however, only after he stayed with her in the Feywild for at least one year.

The prince saw a year of his life as a small price to pay, so he accepted the hag's terms. The year seemed to drag on and on, and when it finally ended, {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} found himself with only one way to get home: a path that, according to Endelyn, is visible "only in the light of the eight beacons." The simple goal of lighting the beacons has been repeatedly thwarted by the perytons, who revel in {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW}'s despair. Each time he lights a beacon, the perytons snuff it out, yet {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} is too stubborn and determined to give up. He hopes the perytons will grow bored of their antics and leave him alone eventually. He is, however, misguided in that expectation.
{@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} is a {@creature knight} (chaotic good) with these changes:

items: {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} is unarmed and unarmored (AC 10).
He speaks Common and Elvish, and he has {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.
Hij heeft voordeel bij reddingen tegen het zijn {@condition charmed}, en magie kan hem niet in slaap brengen.

entries: If the characters speak with {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW}, he tells his tragic story and shares the following information in the course of a conversation:

items: Endelyn's castle is a grand and terrible theater where plays are performed on the stage for her amusement.
Endelyn is always trying to recruit new actors to perform in her theater.

The perytons were once a troupe of actors called the Greyhawk Mummers. Endelyn invited them to Motherhorn, where they performed pantomimes. ({@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} attended several of these performances.) When their popularity made them haughty and difficult to control, Endelyn locked them up. When they begged to be set free, the hag honored their request by releasing them into the wild—but only after she turned them into perytons. The transformation deprived them of speech, yet they retain their theatrical behavior.

entries: {@adventure Appendix D|WBtW|9} has additional roleplaying notes for {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW}.

entries.name: Performing Perytons
entries: As {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} related, the perytons used to be human pantomimists known as the Greyhawk Mummers—so named because they got their start performing in the Free City of Greyhawk on the world of Oerth. The perytons remember their former lives as actors, and though they understand Common and Elvish, they can no longer speak.

Archillus and Mortia are the leading male and leading female of the troupe. The others are Verna (Mortia's bitter understudy), Mauldower (an old-timer who believes his cohorts are amateurs), Angara (the troupe's matriarchal dame), Gorgenal (a jester), Carthasar (a method actor), and Thornelia (a minstrel).

The characters can help {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} without resorting to violence by asking the perytons to perform one of their favorite pantomimes. The perytons are taken aback, in a good way, by the request and appreciate the opportunity to entertain a crowd. They perform a pantomime show that lasts nearly an hour, then take their bows silently. If everyone in the party claps or cheers, the perytons are thrilled and fly off. If one or more party members fail to clap or cheer after the perytons perform, the perytons become furious and attack the party. Once the perytons are placated or slain, {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} can light the beacons without further interference.

The characters can also impress the perytons by putting on a performance of their own. Impressing the perytons requires the performing characters to succeed on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Performance}) group check. Any character who received an acting lesson from Candlefoot in the {@area Witchlight Carnival|0f5|x} has advantage on this check. If the group check succeeds, the perytons regard the characters as kindred spirits and will stop bothering {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} if the characters ask nicely.

entries.name: Unicorn Horn
entries: If the {@adventure Story Tracker|WBtW|11} indicates that the unicorn horn is here, it is in the possession of the peryton named Archillus. {@creature Skabatha Nightshade|WBtW} dropped it accidentally while flying over the mountains, and Archillus found it and kept it. He gives it to the characters if they applaud his performance or if they put on a successful performance of their own. They can also take the horn from his dead body.

entries.name: Lighting the Beacons
entries: If the perytons are placated or otherwise dealt with, {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} can safely light the beacons. {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} knows that he must be the one to light the beacons, for only then will they show him the way home. The characters are free to stay and watch as he climbs to the top of each rocky column and lights its beacon. It takes 8 hours for him to light all eight beacons—enough time for the characters to take a long rest if they choose to stick around.

Each beacon consists of an 8-foot-diameter stone brazier filled with coals that catch fire easily, even while wet. To light a brazier, one need only touch the coals with the head of a lit torch or some other open flame. If {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} is allowed to light all eight beacons by himself, read:

Beneath the light of all the beacons, you see reflected in the mirror-like surface of the lake a forest of ancient trees shrouded in mist. {@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} bows to you, then leaps into the lake. As he plunges into the water, ripples fan out across its surface. After a minute, the forest scene fades away and the beacons go out one by one.
{@creature Alagarthas|WBtW} is transported safely back to his home in the Misty Forest on the world of Toril, as is any other creature that enters the water before the scene fades away.

Any character who lights all eight beacons without assistance causes the lake to display an image of whatever place that character calls home. The image lasts for 1 minute, and any creature that enters the water during that time is transported to this destination. There's no way to get back to the lake, making it a one-way trip.

entries.title: The korreds plant stone sculptures of themselves outside the mine to frighten the brigganock miners

entries.name: Brigganock Mine
entries: Whenever a mortal makes a wish on the Material Plane, an echo of that wish crystallizes inside a stone buried deep in the earth of the Feywild. Tiny creatures called {@creature Brigganock|WBtW|brigganocks} excavate mines beneath the surface of Yon to search for these wish stones. A secret route to Motherhorn lies hidden deep inside the mine; the brigganocks reveal it only to those who earn their respect.
Read the following boxed text aloud when the characters first approach the mine's entrance:

You hear the sound of hundreds of tiny pickaxes and hammers chipping away at stone. It emanates from the mouth of a cave that has fingers of rock reaching skyward above it. Statues of irate, hairy creatures with cloven hooves are positioned so that they lean around trees and peer over boulders, all staring balefully at the cave entrance.
The statues depict korreds and are harmless. They were carved and placed here by real korreds to frighten and intimidate the brigganocks (see "{@area Lockbury Henge|2b0|x}" earlier in the chapter).

entries.name: Entering the Mine
entries: If one or more characters enter the mine, read:
As soon as you step inside the cave, the tapping noise stops.
As the characters head deeper into the mine, the sound of hammering resumes, coming up from the depths.

entries.name: Exploring the Mine
entries: The mine is a twisting labyrinth of 8-foot-high, 3-foot-wide tunnels that corkscrew into the ground. The brigganocks made these tunnels big enough to accommodate ponies (which they use as beasts of burden) and their good friend {@creature Molliver|WBtW}, whom the characters will encounter if they head deeper into the mine (see "{@creature Molliver|WBtW}" below).

The characters encounter no brigganocks in the upper reaches of the mine, but the sound of activity persists. After 10 minutes of navigating the mine, each character must succeed on a DC 19 Constitution saving throw or fall asleep for 1 hour, lulled into a magical slumber by the rhythmic racket of the miners. On a successful save, a creature is immune to this effect permanently. Elves and other creatures that can't be put to sleep by magic are also immune to the effect. Creatures that are put to sleep in this way can't be awakened early by any means short of a {@spell wish} spell.

Eight {@creature Brigganock|WBtW|brigganocks} (see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}) arrive 5 minutes later, each one pushing a tiny wheelbarrow that contains ropes and pitons. If they encounter party members who are still awake, the brigganocks look surprised, turn their wheelbarrows around, and retreat whence they came, passing {@creature Molliver|WBtW} as they return to the mine's depths (see "{@creature Molliver|WBtW}" below). Otherwise, if there's no one around to stop them, they use their Time Lapse action to rapidly pin sleeping party members to the floor using their hammers, pitons, and ropes.

Creatures pinned to the floor are {@condition restrained}, {@condition prone}, and unable to stand up until they free themselves or are released by someone else. A creature can use an action to try to snap the ropes that bind it or to wriggle free of them, doing so with a successful DC 16 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check or DC 16 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. If a creature has a knife or other sharp tool that it can reach while pinned to the floor, it can use an action to try to saw through its ropes, doing so with a successful DC 16 Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check. A creature that gets free can use an action to release a creature that is still pinned (no ability check required).

entries.name: Wish-Come-True
entries: The brigganocks hail from a city called Wish-come-true, which is hidden deep beneath the mountains. Its buildings are adorned with glittering gems made from cut wish stones. Hidden behind thick rock walls and powerful illusions, the city can never be found by outsiders, nor can it be scried upon using divination magic.

entries.name: Molliver
entries: If the entire party is pinned to the floor by the brigganocks, the characters awaken to find themselves staring up at a human standing in their midst. Otherwise, they encounter this individual if they chase after any fleeing brigganocks or head deeper into the mine:

A tall, slender human clad in dark leather armor greets you, their friendly face brightly illuminated by a tiny wisp of light that floats next to a mouse-sized creature perched on the human's shoulder.
"Greetings, trespassers," says the human with a smile. "Didn't anyone ever teach you how to knock?"

The armored figure is {@creature Molliver|WBtW} (see {@area appendix B|4a5|x}), and the creature on {@creature Molliver|WBtW}'s shoulder is Trig, a {@creature brigganock|WBtW} (see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}). Characters who have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notice two more {@creature Brigganock|WBtW|brigganocks} hiding on {@creature Molliver|WBtW}'s person—one tucked comfortably in a belt pouch and the other peering over the rim of {@creature Molliver|WBtW}'s left boot. Their names are Zarli and Oyla.

The brigganocks are happy to have {@creature Molliver|WBtW} as their spokesperson and chief advisor when it comes to dealing with outsiders. {@creature Molliver|WBtW} has become embroiled in the brigganocks' quarrel with the korreds and assumes—as the brigganocks do—that the characters were sent by the korreds or their evil ally, Creeping Lyn, to slay brigganocks and steal wish stones.

The characters can convince {@creature Molliver|WBtW} of their true intentions with a successful DC 9 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, or they can trick {@creature Molliver|WBtW} into letting them venture deeper into the mines with a successful DC 9 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check. Once convinced that the characters are opposed to Creeping Lyn and not conspiring with the korreds, {@creature Molliver|WBtW} instructs the brigganocks to release any character who is still pinned to the floor and shares the following information with conscious characters:

items: Creeping Lyn kidnapped the brigganocks' best architect, Golmo, who now toils in Motherhorn, designing new contraptions for the hag.

The korreds provide Creeping Lyn with locks of their magic hair, which she uses to build her contraptions. (This is partially false. The hag cuts the korreds' hair without their consent; they are not her allies.)
The brigganocks work their mine at all hours because they know the noise aggravates the korreds.

entries: {@creature Molliver|WBtW} dodges questions about how they came to be with the brigganocks but admits to being a member of Valor's Call, an adventuring group that has been hunting a pack of villains called the League of Malevolence. {@creature Molliver|WBtW} assumes that the other members of Valor's Call are safe at Zybilna's palace and is unaware of all that has happened there of late (see {@adventure chapter 5|WBtW|5}). Knowing that their friends are in trouble doesn't change {@creature Molliver|WBtW}'s desire to remain with the brigganocks, who need protection.

entries.name: Rivenwish Chasm
entries: After conferring with Trig, {@creature Molliver|WBtW} says that if the characters complete a test set before them, the brigganocks will show them a secret route to Motherhorn. To pass the test, the characters must cross Rivenwish Chasm, a gash in the earth into which the brigganocks hurl malignant wish stones (the ones born out of evil wishes). {@creature Molliver|WBtW} and their brigganock companions lead the characters through several tunnels that lead to the chasm but stop short of entering it:

The route ends at a gaping chasm, on the far side of which is a grotto full of stalactites and stalagmites. A truss bridge constructed of intricate wooden struts and beams spans the one-hundred-foot gap across the chasm. Beneath the bridge is darkness dotted with purple lights.
"Well," declares {@creature Molliver|WBtW}, "here we are at jolly old Rivenwish Chasm. Best stay on the bridge and not dillydally."
The bridge is 5 feet wide, 100 feet long, and sturdy. Each 5-foot section of the wooden structure has AC 15, 30 hit points, and immunity to fire, poison, and psychic damage.

The chasm is haunted by three {@creature Flameskull||flameskulls}—the remains of darklings who suffered from vertigo and fell to their doom before reaching the bridge's halfway point. The flameskulls hide under the bridge's midpoint. Characters who have passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) scores of 10 or higher aren't surprised when the flameskulls emerge from hiding and take up positions 10 feet above the bridge.

The flameskulls speak Elvish and Sylvan. Their names are Weaugh, Teaugh, and Peaugh. The flameskulls are hostile toward all other creatures in the chasm and attack without provocation. They become indifferent toward any creature that walks or runs across the bridge and makes it past the midpoint (regardless of the direction it is traveling). Weaugh, Teaugh, and Peaugh congratulate the creature on making it this far.

A character toward whom the flameskulls are indifferent can use an action to try to convince the flameskulls to let the party pass, doing so with a successful DC 13 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. If the flameskulls are persuaded to allow safe passage, they apologize for their unprovoked hostility before returning to their hiding spots under the bridge. From that point on, all characters in the party can cross the chasm safely in either direction.

There's no chance of a character accidentally falling off the bridge or being knocked off the bridge by the flameskulls. The chasm is 200 feet deep, and its bottom is strewn with hundreds of malignant wish stones that give off purple light. These wish stones are unrefined lumps of crystal that shed bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet; any good-aligned creature that has one or more of them in its possession feels mildly nauseated, although this nausea has no game effect. Hags, liches, and other evil spellcasters can find macabre uses for these malignant wish stones, which otherwise have no value.

entries.name: Obud's Grotto
entries: When the characters reach the subterranean grotto on the far side of the bridge, read:
In the center of the grotto is a piebald pony wearing blinders. A small wooden hut is strapped to its back, and a faint clatter can be heard from inside the hut.

{@creature Molliver|WBtW} and their brigganock companions explain to the characters that the hut is the home of Obud, the oldest {@creature brigganock|WBtW} (see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8}) living in the mine at present. Securely fastened to a {@creature pony} named Keg is Obud's hut, where he appraises gemstones brought to him by other brigganocks. When Obud wants to dismount from the pony, he lowers a rope ladder attached to one of the pony's saddle straps.

The pony doesn't startle easily and allows characters to approach it without a fuss, and it eagerly devours any apples and carrots that the characters have to offer. If someone knocks on the hut's tiny door, read:

The door swings open, and a tiny, wrinkled creature hobbles into view, accompanied by a wispy bulb of light. The old brigganock peers at you through tiny spectacles and says in Common, "Big folk. How wonderful."

Obud is old and tired, but neither too old nor too tired to show the characters hospitality. He welcomes them to his grotto, introduces them to Keg, and asks them why they've crossed the chasm to see him. If they inquire about the secret tunnel to Motherhorn, he says, "Ah, yes. Creeping Lyn's Theater of Terror. A dreadful place indeed." Obud suggests a trade: knowledge of the location of the tunnel in exchange for something that would benefit him and his fellow brigganocks. Ending the quarrel between the brigganocks and the korreds would suffice (see the "{@area Brigganocks and Korreds|2b2|x}" sidebar earlier in the chapter). Obud also accepts tasty food, including but not limited to sweets, a wheel of cheese, or a head of lettuce. Candy from the {@area Witchlight Carnival|0c1|x} or the {@area goblin market|232|x} in Loomlurch would suffice.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Brigganocks shape and cut good wish stones into sparkling gems. Obud has three such gems in his hut, neatly laid out on a tiny rug. Two of the gems are worth 100 gp, and the third is worth 500 gp. Obud has appraised the gemstones and is waiting for their rightful brigganock owners to return and collect them. Stealing these gems violates the rule of ownership (see "{@area Rules of Conduct|105|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}). Characters who steal from Obud receive no further help from him.

entries.title: Obud's pony likes apples and carrots

entries.name: Tunnel to Motherhorn
entries: A permanent illusion of a rock wall conceals an 8-foot-high, 3-foot-wide tunnel in the back wall of Obud's grotto. This secret tunnel leads to a storage room ({@area area M12|31c|x}) beneath Motherhorn's stage. The illusory wall has no substance, which means that creatures and objects can pass right through it. A successful casting of {@spell dispel magic} (DC 19) causes the illusory wall to disappear.

Obud informs the characters that Creeping Lyn is unaware of this tunnel's existence ("Let's keep it that way, aye?" he adds). The characters can return to the grotto through the tunnel whenever they want, provided they are on good terms with the brigganocks. If the characters use the tunnel without Obud's consent, brigganock miners spend the next 8 hours collapsing the tunnel on itself, preventing the characters from returning to the mine by that route.

entries.name: Wish Stones
entries: Check the {@adventure Story Tracker|WBtW|11} to see if any of the characters made wishes while with Northwind (see "{@area Hour 1: Welcome Gifts|0ec|x}" in {@adventure chapter 1|WBtW|1}). If so, echoes of their wishes have crystallized in the depths of Yon and were mined by the brigganocks. As the characters are preparing to leave the mine, a cheerful brigganock named Ajak arrives with a wheelbarrow containing the characters' wish stones. These stones look like round lumps of crystal and have not yet been shaped or cut. If a character's wish was good-natured, its stone glows with golden light (bright light out to a range of 20 feet and dim light for an additional 20 feet). If the wish was evil-natured, its stone glows with purple light (bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet).

Characters whose wishes were good-hearted can keep their stones as mementos or leave the stones with the brigganocks to be cut into sparkling gemstones—a process that takes 8 hours with the help of the brigganocks' Time Lapse action. (The characters can return to the mine to collect their gems after attending to other matters.) A fairly common wish produces a 50 gp gemstone, an unusual wish produces a 100 gp gemstone, and an exceptionally original wish produces a 500 gp gemstone (as determined by you). Once a wish stone is cut into a gem, it loses its magic and ceases to glow.

The brigganocks don't make gemstones out of malignant wish stones. Instead, they toss these purple-glowing stones into Rivenwish Chasm unless the characters who created them want to take the stones with them. Mild nausea plagues any good-aligned creature that has one or more of these stones in its possession, though this nausea has no game effect.

entries.name: Development
entries: The "{@area Brigganocks and Korreds|2b2|x}" sidebar earlier in the chapter describes how the characters can facilitate a truce between the two groups of Fey and unite them against {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}. If the korreds and brigganocks end their quarrel and launch an assault on {@adventure Motherhorn|WBtW|4}, {@creature Molliver|WBtW} accompanies the combined force.

entries.name: Motherhorn
entries: Motherhorn is Yon's tallest peak, into which Endelyn has carved an amphitheater of the same name. Macabre moldings, friezes, and gargoyles embellish the amphitheater's grim architecture.
Recurring features include the following elements:

items.name: Ceilings
items.entry: Unless otherwise noted, ceilings throughout Motherhorn are 15 feet high. The amphitheater is open to the sky, as are the various stone balconies.

items.name: Curtains
items.entry: The curtains that hang across doorways are made of black fabric, and each curtain has been enchanted so that sound doesn't pass through it while it is closed.

items.name: Doors
items.entry: With the exception of the stone doors that block the main entrance ({@area area M1|2e4|x}) and the prison ({@area area M17|32f|x}), all doors in Motherhorn are made of sturdy wood with iron handles and fittings. Each one has a bronze knocker on one side shaped like a smiling theater mask; a similar knocker on the opposite side is shaped like a frowning theater mask. None of these doors have locks.

items.name: Light
items.entry: Glowing orbs of red glass are set into wrought-iron wall sconces throughout Motherhorn. Each orb sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet. Removing an orb from its sconce causes the orb's light to go dark until it is returned to a sconce.

entries.name: Entering Motherhorn
entries: The characters can get into Motherhorn in one of several ways:

items: They can use the front door ({@area area M1|2e4|x}).

They can use climbing gear or magic to scale the walls. Doing so allows them to enter the amphitheater ({@area area M2|2e8|x}) or reach one of the higher balconies (areas {@area M15|328|x}, {@area M16|32a|x}, {@area M20|33f|x}, and {@area M21|34a|x}).
A magical tornado (see "{@area Random Encounters in Yon|2ae|x}" earlier in this chapter) might deposit them in the amphitheater.
They can use the secret tunnel dug by the brigganocks ({@area area M12|31c|x}).

entries: Characters who obtained invitations from a pageant wagon (see "{@area Random Encounters in Yon|2ad|x}" earlier in the chapter) are entitled to a free audience with Endelyn. Any member of the theater staff can accept the characters' invitations and escort them safely to the hag's audience chamber ({@area area M18|338|x}).

If one or more characters claim to be performers looking for work at the theater, they are granted an audition, during which they will be required to perform a play for Endelyn's pleasure (see "{@area A Tragedy in the Making|2db|x}" later in the chapter for details).

entries.name: Approaching Motherhorn
entries: Characters who use the brigganocks' secret tunnel to reach Motherhorn arrive at area M12.
If the characters instead approach Motherhorn using an aboveground route, use the following boxed text to describe what they see:

Looming above you is an ominous gray citadel hewn out of the mountaintop. The path leading to it is winding and precipitous. Wind swirls around its towers, and ravens cluster and caw in its granite nooks. A crooked finger of lightning strikes a metal rod protruding from the topmost spire, and the sound of applause drifts over the citadel's battlements.
The mountain path ends at a spiral staircase that climbs sixty feet to a balcony made of weathered gray stone.

If Trinket, Bauble, and Charm left Hither and returned to Motherhorn in their rain cloud balloon (see {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2| D10. Trinket, Bauble, and Charm's}), it is tethered to a balcony ({@area area M16|32a|x}) and visible to all who approach. Describe the balloon as follows:
A large balloon made of bulging rain clouds is tethered to a much higher stone balcony that is well beyond reach. The balloon has a merchant's stall instead of an ordinary basket dangling from it.

If Gleam is with the characters, she warns them that {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} won't be happy to see her again. If the characters tell her to remain outside while they rescue her sibling, Gleam does so grudgingly. Amidor and Pollenella remain by the elf's side for company.

If Gleam accompanies the characters into Motherhorn, she avoids combat while urging the characters to escort her to the prison ({@area area M17|32f|x}), where her sister is being held. Gleam has spent enough time in Motherhorn to be familiar with the theater's layout, though she knows nothing about the secret brigganock tunnel that leads to {@area area M12|31c|x}.

entries.name: Where's Endelyn?
entries: When she's not granting audiences, Endelyn keeps to the following routine:

items: Twice per day, Endelyn watches plays from one of the balconies ({@area area M21|34a|x}). Occasionally, when the mood strikes her, she swoops down to the stage ({@area area M2|2e8|x}) on her {@item ornithopter of flying|WBtW} (see {@adventure appendix A|WBtW|6}) in the closing minutes of a play to steal the show.

While plays are being rehearsed in the amphitheater, she spends her time in {@area area M19|33d|x}, peering down at the Orrery of Tragedies in {@area area M14|323|x} and using a quill pen to transcribe its prophecies into a tiny black book.
During the eight hours when no plays are being rehearsed or performed, she sleeps standing up inside a glass-paneled wardrobe in {@area area M22|34c|x}.

entries.name: Bargaining with Endelyn
entries: When the characters come to Motherhorn, Endelyn has foreseen their arrival and is expecting them. If you used the "Lost Things" adventure hook and the {@adventure Story Tracker|WBtW|11} indicates that Endelyn has one or more things that the characters need, she is willing to trade away these possessions one by one, but only after the characters agree to perform on her stage.

Regardless of what the characters want from her, Endelyn typically requires them to perform for her before she will bargain with them. If she deems the characters' performance satisfactory (see "{@area A Tragedy in the Making|2db|x}" below), she leads the party to her audience chamber ({@area area M18|338|x}) and conducts negotiations there. If the deems their performance unsatisfactory, she doesn't feel bound by the rule of reciprocity (see "{@area Rules of Conduct|105|x}" in {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2}) to grant them an audience.

entries.name: Fey to the Rescue!
entries: If the characters helped the korreds and brigganocks settle their differences earlier in the chapter, they offer to help the characters in return. Twelve {@creature Brigganock|WBtW|brigganocks} hanging from the beards of three {@creature Korred|VGM|korreds} arrive on the outskirts of Motherhorn at an agreed-upon time, ready to spring into action if the characters call for aid (see {@adventure appendix C|WBtW|8} for their stat blocks).

If one or more characters cry out for assistance in Motherhorn, the brigganocks and korreds hear the call for help and react quickly. The korreds barrel out of the secret tunnel in {@area area M12|31c|x} or scale the theater's walls using ropes made of korred hair, and the brigganocks use their {@spell darkness}, {@spell faerie fire}, {@spell silence}, and {@spell sleep} spells to confound and neutralize Endelyn's minions. The Fey try not to steal the show; their goal is to distract Endelyn's minions so the characters can wriggle out of a tight spot or confront the hag without her lackeys.

If the characters decline to perform a play for her, Endelyn demands that they leave at once, ordering her {@creature Darkling|VGM|darklings} to attack characters who refuse to do so. In the ensuing fracas, characters who are reduced to 0 hit points are knocked {@condition unconscious}, stripped of their gear, and locked in the prison ({@area area M17|32f|x}) until Endelyn decides what to do with them. (Stagefright leads the way to the prison, since his fool's scepter is needed to open the prison's front door.) If Endelyn finds no other use for imprisoned characters, she turns them into masks using the arcane device in {@area area M8|309|x}.

Characters who come to Motherhorn bearing invitations from a pageant wagon (see "{@area Random Encounters in Yon|2ad|x}" earlier in the chapter) can skip the performance and jump straight to the private audience.

Assuming that the characters' performance or the presentation of their invitations puts Endelyn in a bargaining mood, she agrees to part with one creature or object in her possession, but only if the characters give her one of the following items in exchange:

items.name: Shadow
items.entry: If a character agrees to give up their shadow, Endelyn uses her {@item scissors of shadow snipping|WBtW} (see {@adventure appendix A|WBtW|6}) to snip it off.

items.name: Gloam the Cat
items.entry: Endelyn accuses her sister, {@creature Bavlorna Blightstraw|WBtW}, of stealing her cat, {@creature Gloam|WBtW}. Endelyn wants the characters to travel to Bavlorna's cottage in Downfall (see {@area chapter 2|1a3|x}), find her cat, and return it to her. (Endelyn doesn't know that Bavlorna killed and stuffed the cat, but she wants it back regardless of its condition.)

items.name: Unicorn Horn
items.entry: Endelyn claims that her sister Skabatha recently lost a unicorn horn, and Endelyn wants the character to find the horn and bring it to her. (Refer to the {@adventure Story Tracker|WBtW|11} for the unicorn horn's location, though any unicorn's horn will do.) Endelyn mentions in passing that the unicorn whose horn was lost is still alive, although transformed into a rocking horse that {@creature Skabatha Nightshade|WBtW} uses as a flying mount.

entries: If Endelyn has more things in her possession that the characters want, she is willing to enter into a separate bargain for each one. Magic items fashioned from lost things are kept in {@area area M22|34c|x}.

entries.name: Endelyn's Escape
entries: Endelyn is loath to leave Motherhorn, but if her survival depends on it, she moves to {@area area M21|34a|x} and uses her {@item ornithopter of flying|WBtW} to retreat to the Palace of Heart's Desire. Her sisters, if present, flee to the palace as well (Bavlorna on her lily pad and Skabatha on her rocking horse).

entries.title: A tiefling adventurer performs a play, hoping to win an audience with {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW}

entries.name: A Tragedy in the Making
entries: Motherhorn's amphitheater is where tragic plays are performed daily for {@creature Endelyn Moongrave|WBtW} to enjoy. The characters might choose to perform on stage for one or more of the following reasons:

items: In order to acquire something or someone in Endelyn's possession, the characters might need to perform a play to put the hag in a bargaining mood (see "{@area Bargaining with Endelyn|2d8|x}" above).
The characters might intend to uphold a bargain made with {@creature Skabatha Nightshade|WBtW} (see "{@area Bargaining with Skabatha|225|x}" in {@adventure chapter 3|WBtW|3}).
The characters might want to create a distraction, and performing a play is the best way to keep Endelyn and her minions preoccupied.

entries: While the play is going on, one or more characters might try to sneak off and explore other areas of Motherhorn on their own, splitting the party. If that occurs, resolve what happens to these wandering characters after the play has run its course.

entries.name: Preparing for the Play
entries: Characters who choose to perform a play are met by Motherhorn's master of ceremonies, Stagefright, who is a {@creature goblin boss} (chaotic neutral). Describe this meeting as follows:

A goblin in a jester's costume taps his clownish scepter on the floor to get your attention and says, "To impress the Dame of Unhappy Endings, you will need to perform a tragedy—something gruesome, depressing, and darkly humorous. I have just the play!" A rolled-up script suddenly appears in his hand. "Normally we would have several hours to prepare, but alas, time is of the essence. Since you don't have time to memorize all the lines, we'll need to improvise." Tossing the script over one shoulder, he says, "Worry not! I'll feed you lines from the wings if you get stuck!"

Have each player roll once on the Performers' Roles table to determine what role Stagefright assigns to that player's character. If two players get the same result, Stagefright lets them decide which one of them takes that role before suggesting another role for the other character (choose a table entry that hasn't already been assigned). Allow characters to invent new roles for themselves if they don't like the ones they're assigned. If a character wants to play a talking pumpkin or a bored treant, let it happen!

entries.caption: Performers' Roles
rows: Honorable knight risen from the dead

entries: Once all the characters have roles, Stagefright leads them to a prop storeroom ({@area area M4a|2f0|x}) and says, "Find whatever you can make use of in this mess!" The characters are allowed 20 minutes to don costumes and select props appropriate for their assigned roles. When they're ready, Stagefright leads them through the dressing room ({@area area M5|2f5|x}) to the performers' quarters ({@area area M6|2fb|x}), whereupon he says, "The play begins in ten minutes!"
